Boning Li⋆, Jake Perazzone†, Ananthram Swami†, and Santiago Segarra⋆
⋆Rice University, USA           †US DEVCOM Army Research Lab., USA
Abstract

We propose a novel data-driven approach to allocate transmit power for federated learning (FL) over interference-limited wireless networks. The proposed method is useful in challenging scenarios where the wireless channel is changing during the FL training process and when the training data are not independent and identically distributed (non-i.i.d.) on the local devices. Intuitively, the power policy is designed to optimize the information received at the server end during the FL process under communication constraints. Ultimately, our goal is to improve the accuracy and efficiency of the global FL model being trained. The proposed power allocation policy is parameterized using graph convolutional networks (GCNs), and the associated constrained optimization problem is solved through a primal-dual (PD) algorithm. Theoretically, we show that the formulated problem has a zero duality gap and, once the power policy is parameterized, optimality depends on how expressive this parameterization is. Numerically, we demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing baselines under different wireless channel settings and varying degrees of data heterogeneity.

Index Terms:
Federated learning, graph neural networks, power allocation, primal-dual learning, wireless interference networks.

I Introduction

Federated learning (FL) enables collaborative training involving multiple workers and one (or more) server(s) [2]. In an iterative manner, a global model is first broadcast to all workers and then updated by integrating local models from workers that participate in the current iteration. Those local models are trained exclusively using the on-device datasets of the corresponding workers. Since only model parameters are shared and no explicit transmission of raw data ever occurs, FL is particularly favorable in settings where privacy concerns or policy constraints limit or restrict data sharing, such as in autonomous driving [3] and digital healthcare [4]. Given the iterative nature of FL, a large number of local model integration steps may be necessary until the convergence of the global model. In many studies [5, 6, 7], it is shown that communications between the workers and the server are a major bottleneck of FL performance. While traditional wired communication is being replaced with fast and reliable wireless connections as in the 5G mobile network, smart home devices, and unmanned aerial systems, the growing computational power of edge devices has increased interest in studying FL scenarios where the data is located at the edge of wireless networks [8, 9, 10, 11, 12].

The specific demands of FL motivate many novel problems in the management of wireless networks. For example, one may seek to perform power allocation to achieve faster convergence of the global model, where a smart power policy is essential to ensuring the quality of wireless services [13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18]. To give a more specific instance, [16] proposed a joint optimization scheme of power, worker, and resource management, taking into account the impact of wireless factors on the FL convergence rate. However, only static channels were considered, making it rather impractical for real-world deployment where the required duration of the FL process may well exceed the channel coherence time. Without knowing the wireless channels a priori, [17] and [18] have leveraged multi-armed bandit worker scheduling to reduce FL time consumptions in the presence of heterogeneous data and fluctuating resources, respectively. However, their applicability is limited due to the assumption of orthogonal channels, which over-simplifies the power optimization in most realistic scenarios.

Outside of the FL context, power allocation problems usually seek to maximize a problem-specific objective subject to simple constraints [19, 20, 21, 22]. The objective could be sum-rate, energy efficiency, or proportional fairness, with typical constraints being a box constraint on allocated power. Challenging power allocation problems are often formulated in interference-limited networks. These networks differ from orthogonal channels, where signals are isolated to prevent interference. Instead, they involve non-orthogonal channels sharing the same time and frequency resources, potentially improving capacity and reducing latency but compromising link reliability [23]. Mathematically, this introduces NP-hard optimization challenges, as the aforementioned objectives adopt sum-of-fractions forms due to the incorporation of interference [24, 25]. Since the globally optimal solutions are practically infeasible for moderately-sized networks (tens of workers) [26], approximate optimization and statistical learning methods have been exploited to achieve efficient and near-optimal power policies. For instance, [27, 28] appealed to matching theory, [29, 30] to Lagrangian dual decomposition, and [31, 32, 33] to successive concave approximation. Turning to another set of methods, machine learning – in particular, graph neural networks (GNNs) – has been recently applied to solve power allocation problems [34, 35, 36, 37, 38, 39]. For example, to maximize sum-rate in interference networks, a suboptimal power allocation algorithm was enhanced with augmented parameters learned by graph convolutional networks (GCNs) for both single-input single-output [38] and multiple-input multiple-output [39] systems. Compared to this body of research, FL demands extra, often non-convex constraints, like imposing limits on the time and energy consumed by uplink transmissions.

In light of this concern, the primal-dual (PD) algorithm is often considered for such optimization under non-convex constraints in a wide range of wireless [40] and safe reinforcement learning [41] settings. Drawing inspiration from this class of research, we propose to tackle the wireless FL-oriented power allocation problem with a learned PD approach through GCNs. Our proposed approach is rooted in a PD framework, inheriting its advantages such as the feasibility through penalty terms, the convexity of dual problems, and the iterative resolution of less complex subproblems. At the same time, we harness the power of a data-driven approach by incorporating the topological nature of wireless network data in our neural architecture. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first GCN-based power policy optimized by the PD method for FL in interference wireless networks. We provide theoretical guarantees for the proposed method and also demonstrate its state-of-the-art performance in multiple independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) and non-i.i.d. scenarios. Ultimately, optimizing transmit power can enhance the global FL model’s performance, since there is less transmission noise, higher data availability, and enhanced communication robustness during the collaborative training process.

Contributions. The main contributions of this work are:

  • i)

    We formulate the power allocation problem under FL requirements as a maximization problem under non-convex conditional expectation constraints, to which we propose a solution based on a GCN-parameterized PD approach.

  • ii)

    We prove that our approach has a zero duality gap under mild conditions and universal parameterization.

  • iii)

    Through numerical experiments on simulated wireless channels and real-world datasets, we validate the effectiveness of the proposed FL power allocation approach in both i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. cases.

Paper outline. In Section II, we present the system model and formulate the FL power allocation as a non-convex constrained optimization problem. In Section IV, we give an in-depth description of the proposed method along with theoretical proofs of its zero duality gap and of the parameterization suboptimality. In Section V, we discuss numerical experiments and show that the proposed method always outperforms heuristic and topology-agnostic power allocation benchmarks. Finally, we close this paper with conclusions in Section VI.

II System Model

We formally introduce the FL system model and the interference-limited wireless channel model in Sections II-A and II-B, respectively. We provide a precise formulation of power allocation for FL as an optimization problem in Section III.

II-A Federated Learning over Wireless Networks

As depicted in Fig. 1, our wireless FL system consists of a single server and L𝐿L mobile worker devices, in which the server and workers communicate through wireless links.

Each worker i𝑖i collects local data 𝐗i=[𝐱i(1),…,𝐱i(ki)]subscript𝐗𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖1…superscriptsubscript𝐱𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖{\mathbf{X}}_{i}{=}[{\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{(1)},...,{\mathbf{x}}_{i}^{(k_{i})}], where kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} is the number of data samples in i𝑖i. Subsequently, the total number of training data samples is K=∑i=1Lki𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑖1subscript𝑘𝑖K{=}\sum^{L}_{i=1}{k_{i}} and the complete dataset 𝒳={𝐗1,…,𝐗L}𝒳subscript𝐗1…subscript𝐗𝐿{\mathcal{X}}{=}\{{\mathbf{X}}_{1},...,{\mathbf{X}}_{L}\}. We will assume that 𝒳𝒳{\mathcal{X}} is i.i.d. across all workers unless explicitly stated otherwise. Much like any other machine learning problems, FL takes the general form of minimizing an objective function but for all workers: min𝐰​∑iLfi​(𝐰)subscript𝐰superscriptsubscript𝑖𝐿subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰\min\limits_{{\mathbf{w}}}\sum_{i}^{L}f_{i}({\mathbf{w}}), where fi​(𝐰)=ℓ​(𝐗i;𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰ℓsubscript𝐗𝑖𝐰f_{i}({\mathbf{w}}){\,=\,}\ell({\mathbf{X}}_{i};{\mathbf{w}}) denotes a local loss, such as quadratic loss for regression tasks and cross-entropy for classification tasks. Workers start each round of local optimization with the latest global model. The nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}} FL iteration, for example, begins with the following assignment: 𝐰i,n=𝐰n−1subscript𝐰𝑖𝑛subscript𝐰𝑛1{\mathbf{w}}_{i,n}{\,=\,}{\mathbf{w}}_{n-1}, where 𝐰i,nsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑛{\mathbf{w}}_{i,n} denotes the model to be updated at worker i𝑖i and 𝐰n−1subscript𝐰𝑛1{\mathbf{w}}_{n-1} the global model resulting from the last iteration. Following this, each worker updates their parameters 𝐰i,nsubscript𝐰𝑖𝑛{\mathbf{w}}_{i,n} based on local data and uploads these to the server, and the server aggregates those into a global one via 𝐰n=1K​∑i=1Lki​𝐰i,nsubscript𝐰𝑛1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖𝑛{\mathbf{w}}_{n}{\,=\,}\frac{1}{K}\sum_{i=1}^{L}k_{i}{\mathbf{w}}_{i,n}, effectively ending the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}} FL iteration.

The wireless setting adds additional complexities to the basic FL setup. Since workers upload local models over wireless links that could be unreliable in realistic environments, the transmission may be corrupted. If no error-detecting codes, e.g., cyclic redundancy check (CRC) codes, are used to eliminate updates that are in error, erroneous transmissions may have a severe impact on FL performance because errors will be aggregated into the global model and contaminate all workers in the next iteration. Even with error detection, frequent transmission errors are still undesirable because we would have to abandon too many updates, which is at least a waste of resources. Additionally, excessive transmission time from only a few workers can significantly slow down the global convergence of the entire system.

II-B Multiuser Interference Network

We consider the uplink of a network with L𝐿L single-antenna mobile workers and an nRsubscript𝑛𝑅n_{R}-antenna central server or base station (BS); see Fig. 2.

Abstracting a signal of potentially variable length transmitted by worker i𝑖i as a complex scalar st,i∈ℂsubscript𝑠t𝑖ℂs_{\text{t},i}{\,\in\,}{\mathbb{C}}, the received signal at the BS is 𝐬r=∑i=1L𝐡i​pi​st,i+𝐧csubscript𝐬rsubscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑖1subscript𝐡𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑠t𝑖subscript𝐧c{{\mathbf{s}}_{\text{r}}}{\,=\,}\sum^{L}_{i=1}{{\mathbf{h}}}_{i}\sqrt{p_{i}}s_{\text{t},i}+{{\mathbf{n}}_{\text{c}}}, where 𝐡i∈ℂnRsubscript𝐡𝑖superscriptℂsubscript𝑛𝑅{{\mathbf{h}}}_{i}{\,\in\,}{\mathbb{C}}^{n_{R}} is the direct channel from i𝑖i to the BS, pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i} denotes the power that worker i𝑖i uses to transmit this signal, and 𝐧c∼𝒩𝒞​(𝟎,𝝈2)similar-tosubscript𝐧csubscript𝒩𝒞0superscript𝝈2{{\mathbf{n}}_{\text{c}}}{\,\sim\,}{\mathcal{N}}_{\mathcal{C}}({\mathbf{0}},\bm{\sigma}^{2}) is the additive complex Gaussian noise at the receiver. We assume perfect channel information, i.e., 𝐡isubscript𝐡𝑖{{\mathbf{h}}}_{i} is known by both the receiver and the transmitter. When matched filters are applied at the receiver, the receive beamform vector for i𝑖i corresponds to 𝐡isubscript𝐡𝑖{\mathbf{h}}_{i}. For a given vector of assigned transmit powers 𝐩=[p1,…,pL]𝐩subscript𝑝1…subscript𝑝𝐿{{\mathbf{p}}}{\,=\,}[p_{1},...,p_{L}], the instantaneous signal-to-interference-plus-noise ratio (SINR) [42] of the link from worker i𝑖i to the BS is given by

SINRi=αi​pi1+∑j≠iβi,j​pj,∀i= 1,…,L,formulae-sequencesubscriptSINR𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖1subscript𝑗𝑖subscript𝛽𝑖𝑗subscript𝑝𝑗for-all𝑖1…𝐿\text{SINR}_{i}{\,=\,}\frac{\alpha_{i}\,p_{i}}{1+\sum_{j\neq i}\beta_{i,j}\,p_{j}},\quad\forall\,i{\,=\,}1,...,L, (1)

αi=‖𝐡i‖2σ2​ and ​βi,j=|𝐡iH​𝐡j|2σ2​‖𝐡i‖2,∀i,j,and ​i≠j.formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼𝑖superscriptnormsubscript𝐡𝑖2superscript𝜎2 and subscript𝛽𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝐡𝐻𝑖subscript𝐡𝑗2superscript𝜎2superscriptnormsubscript𝐡𝑖2for-all𝑖𝑗and 𝑖𝑗\alpha_{i}=\frac{\|{{\mathbf{h}}}_{i}\|^{2}}{\sigma^{2}}\text{ and }\beta_{i,j}=\frac{|{{\mathbf{h}}}^{H}_{i}{{\mathbf{h}}}_{j}|^{2}}{\sigma^{2}\|{{\mathbf{h}}}_{i}\|^{2}},\quad\forall\,i,j,\text{and }i{\,\neq\,}j. (2)

We define the channel-state information (CSI) matrix 𝐇∈ℝL×L𝐇superscriptℝ𝐿𝐿{{\mathbf{H}}}{\,\in\,}{\mathbb{R}}^{L{\times}L} with αisubscript𝛼𝑖\alpha_{i} as its diagonal entries and βi,jsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑗\beta_{i,j} as off-diagonal entries, i.e., Hi,i=αisubscript𝐻𝑖𝑖subscript𝛼𝑖H_{i,i}{\,=\,}\alpha_{i} and Hi,j=βi,jsubscript𝐻𝑖𝑗subscript𝛽𝑖𝑗H_{i,j}{\,=\,}\beta_{i,j} for i≠j𝑖𝑗i{\neq\,}j. Notice that by introducing the CSI matrix, the system can now be interpreted as a directed graph with workers as its nodes and 𝐇𝐇{\mathbf{H}} as its adjacency matrix.

The achievable data rate for worker i𝑖i with bandwidth B𝐵B is Ri​(𝐩,𝐇)=B​log⁡(1+SINRi)subscript𝑅𝑖𝐩𝐇𝐵1subscriptSINR𝑖R_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}}){\,=\,}B\log(1{+}\text{SINR}_{i}), and its transmission time is

where Z​(𝐰i)𝑍subscript𝐰𝑖Z({\mathbf{w}}_{i}) represents the size of the transmitted local model parameters 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖{\mathbf{w}}_{i} in bits, plus supplementary CRC bits. Owing to the fixed model architecture employed, Z​(𝐰i)𝑍subscript𝐰𝑖Z({\mathbf{w}}_{i}) remains constant across all workers.

Other worker-level constants include Pc,isubscript𝑃c𝑖P_{\text{c},i}, namely the static power consumption by worker i𝑖i during the term of transmission, and the computation power consumption coefficient ccomp,isubscript𝑐comp𝑖c_{\text{comp},i}, which is the energy required for computing per bit data, depending on hardware components like the central processing unit (CPU) and microchips. Hence, the total energy consumed by the local training and transmission processes is

etot,i​(𝐩,𝐇)=ccomp,i​Z​(𝐰i)+(pi+Pc,i)​τi,∀i.subscript𝑒tot𝑖𝐩𝐇subscript𝑐comp𝑖𝑍subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑃c𝑖subscript𝜏𝑖for-all𝑖e_{\text{tot},i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}}){\,=\,}c_{\text{comp},i}Z({\mathbf{w}}_{i})+(p_{i}+P_{\text{c},i})\tau_{i},\,\,\,\forall\,i. (4)

For simplicity, we proceed with uniform constants across all workers, i.e., ccomp,i=ccompsubscript𝑐comp𝑖subscript𝑐compc_{\text{comp},i}{\,=\,}c_{\text{comp}} and Pc,i=Pcsubscript𝑃c𝑖subscript𝑃cP_{\text{c},i}{\,=\,}P_{\text{c}}, ∀ifor-all𝑖\forall\,i, and note that the non-uniform case follows exactly the same approach. We assume single-packet transmissions and define the packet error rate (PER)

PERi​(𝐩,𝐇)=1−exp⁡(−mSINRi),∀i,subscriptPER𝑖𝐩𝐇1𝑚subscriptSINR𝑖for-all𝑖\text{PER}_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}})=1-\exp\!\left(-\frac{m}{\text{SINR}_{i}}\right),\forall\,i, (5)

with m𝑚m being a waterfall threshold [16, 43]. CRC is leveraged when a packet containing 𝐰isubscript𝐰𝑖{\mathbf{w}}_{i} arrives at the BS. The probability of the transmission being error-free is 1−PERi1subscriptPER𝑖1{\,-\,}\text{PER}_{i}, namely the packet success rate (PSR). We define a system-level performance metric g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) as the weighted sum of the probabilities of successful transmissions

g​([PSRi]i=1L)=∑i=1Lωi​PSRi,𝑔subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-[]subscriptPSR𝑖𝐿𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿subscript𝜔𝑖subscriptPSR𝑖g\!\left(\left[\,\text{PSR}_{i}\,\right]^{L}_{i=1}\right){\,=\,}\sum_{i=1}^{L}\omega_{i}\,\text{PSR}_{i}, (6)

with ωisubscript𝜔𝑖\omega_{i} being a scalar weight assigned to worker i𝑖i accounting for its data quality and/or other factors such as worker reliability or preference. A basic and common choice under i.i.d. data distribution is to specify ωi=ki/Ksubscript𝜔𝑖subscript𝑘𝑖𝐾\omega_{i}{\,=\,}k_{i}/K, using the data quantity as an indicator of the data quality.

III Problem formulation

Our goal is to find an instantaneous power allocation policy p:ℝL×L→ℝL:𝑝→superscriptℝ𝐿𝐿superscriptℝ𝐿p{\,:\,}{\mathbb{R}}^{L\times L}{\,\rightarrow\,}{\mathbb{R}}^{L} to compute the transmit power magnitudes 𝐩=p​(𝐇)𝐩𝑝𝐇{\mathbf{p}}{\,=\,}p({\mathbf{H}}) for any 𝐇∈ℋ𝐇ℋ{\mathbf{H}}{\,\in\,}{\mathcal{H}}, where ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} denotes a continuous distribution from which varying CSI instances are drawn. Before each uplink transmission, the system should determine for each worker its transmit power by feeding the power policy p𝑝p with the real-time 𝐇𝐇{\mathbf{H}}. After a sufficient number of FL iterations, the global model converges to an optimal point of the global loss function while satisfying the constraints imposed by our physical system. In cases of non-convex optimization, this point of convergence may correspond to a stationary (not necessarily optimal) point. Notice that only the correctly transmitted local models will be aggregated by the server each round. Hence, the update of the global model at the server will be a function of the channel and the power allocation. Without being specific to any certain iteration, it can be expressed as

𝐰​(𝐩,𝐇)=∑i=1Lki​𝐰i​Si​(𝐩,𝐇)∑i=1Lki​Si​(𝐩,𝐇),𝐰𝐩𝐇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖𝐩𝐇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐿subscript𝑘𝑖subscript𝑆𝑖𝐩𝐇{\mathbf{w}}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}}){\,=\,}\frac{\sum_{i=1}^{L}k_{i}{\mathbf{w}}_{i}S_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}})}{\sum_{i=1}^{L}k_{i}S_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}})}, (7)

where Si​(𝐩,𝐇)subscript𝑆𝑖𝐩𝐇S_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}}) is an indicator function denoting whether the server actually aggregates the local model from worker i𝑖i. Only if the allocated pi> 0subscript𝑝𝑖 0p_{i}\,{>}\,0 (i.e., worker i𝑖i performs a transmission) and the server-received packet passes the CRC (i.e., the transmission is error-free), we deem the transmission successful and let Si​(𝐩,𝐇)= 1subscript𝑆𝑖𝐩𝐇1S_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}}){\,=\,}1; otherwise, Si​(𝐩,𝐇)= 0subscript𝑆𝑖𝐩𝐇 0S_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}}){\,=\,}0. In the rare case where no model is correctly transmitted in a certain round, the server retains an unchanged global copy of 𝐰𝐰{\mathbf{w}} from the previous round, and the local models are then rolled back to this global 𝐰𝐰{\mathbf{w}}.

Under the i.i.d. data assumption, the global FL model will benefit from accessing as much local information as possible. Intuitively speaking, this is equivalent to prioritizing transmissions from workers with better links if all workers have an even number of samples, or prioritizing transmissions from workers with more data if all workers are in the same wireless condition. Hence, we adopt the weighted sum of PSR (6) as a proxy for the quality of the global FL model. We now formally state our main problem.

Problem 1.

Determine the optimal power allocation policy p⋆:ℝL×L→ℝL:superscript𝑝⋆→superscriptℝ𝐿𝐿superscriptℝ𝐿p^{\star}:{\mathbb{R}}^{L\times L}{\,\rightarrow\,}{\mathbb{R}}^{L} that solves the following optimization problem

p⋆=superscript𝑝⋆absent\displaystyle p^{\star}{\,=\,} argmaxpg​(𝔼𝐇∼ℋ​[PSR​(𝐩,𝐇)]),subscriptargmax𝑝𝑔subscript𝔼similar-to𝐇ℋdelimited-[]PSR𝐩𝐇\displaystyle\operatornamewithlimits{argmax}_{p}\,\,g\left({\mathbb{E}}_{{\mathbf{H}}{\sim}{\mathcal{H}}}\left[\text{PSR}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}})\right]\right), (P1)
s.t. r0,i≤𝔼𝐇∼ℋ​[Ri​(𝐩,𝐇)​|pi>​0],subscript𝑟0𝑖subscript𝔼similar-to𝐇ℋdelimited-[]subscript𝑅𝑖𝐩𝐇ketsubscript𝑝𝑖0\displaystyle r_{0,i}\leq{\mathbb{E}}_{{\mathbf{H}}{\sim}{\mathcal{H}}}\left[R_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}})\,|\,p_{i}>0\right], (P1a)
e0,i≤𝔼𝐇∼ℋ​[Ri​(𝐩,𝐇)pi+Pc,i​|pi>​0],∀i,subscript𝑒0𝑖subscript𝔼similar-to𝐇ℋdelimited-[]subscript𝑅𝑖𝐩𝐇subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑃c𝑖ketsubscript𝑝𝑖0for-all𝑖\displaystyle{e_{0,i}\leq{\mathbb{E}}_{{\mathbf{H}}{\sim}{\mathcal{H}}}\left[\frac{R_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}})}{p_{i}+P_{\text{c},i}}\,|\,p_{i}>0\right],\forall i,} (P1b)
𝐩=p​(𝐇)∈[0,Pmax],∀𝐇,formulae-sequence𝐩𝑝𝐇0subscript𝑃for-all𝐇\displaystyle{\mathbf{p}}=p({\mathbf{H}}){\,\in\,}[0,P_{\max}],\,\,\,\forall{\mathbf{H}}, (P1c)

where r0,isubscript𝑟0𝑖r_{0,i} and e0,isubscript𝑒0𝑖e_{0,i} are prespecified minimum levels of desired expected data rate and energy efficiency, respectively, for worker i𝑖i. The expectation 𝔼𝐇∼ℋ​[⋅]subscript𝔼similar-to𝐇ℋdelimited-[]⋅{\mathbb{E}}_{{\mathbf{H}}{\sim}{\mathcal{H}}}[\cdot] over the distribution ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} (or simply 𝔼​[⋅]𝔼delimited-[]⋅{\mathbb{E}}[\cdot] in the remainder of this paper) is applied elementwise to the variable in the bracket. Note that, instead of an upper constraint on energy consumption, we place a lower constraint on a variant of its inverse metric in the inequality (P1b) where the left-hand side is converted from (4) such that

e0,i=(etot 0,iZ​(𝐰i)−ccomp)−1,∀i= 1,…,L,formulae-sequencesubscript𝑒0𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑒subscripttot 0𝑖𝑍subscript𝐰𝑖subscript𝑐comp1for-all𝑖1…𝐿e_{0,i}{\,=\,}\!\left(\frac{e_{\text{tot}_{\,0,i}}}{Z({\mathbf{w}}_{i})}-c_{\text{comp}}\right)^{-1},\forall\,i{\,=\,}1,...,L,

which reflects the energy efficiency of worker i𝑖i’s transmission. Hence, higher values in 𝐞0subscript𝐞0{\mathbf{e}}_{0} are generally preferred in an energy-constrained system, indicating more efficient use of energy during wireless transmissions.

To better understand (P1), notice that we are trying to maximize g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) [cf. (6)] applied to the expected probabilities of successful transmissions given a distribution ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} from which the CSI matrix instances are drawn. We seek to maximize this objective subject to three natural constraints. In (P1a), we require the data rate at each worker that transmits, i.e., workers where p> 0𝑝 0p{\,>\,}0, to exceed (in expectation) a prespecified rate r0,isubscript𝑟0𝑖r_{0,i}. In light of expression (3), this requirement can be reinterpreted as demanding a transmission duration shorter than the maximum allowable time for all transmitters with non-zero allocated power. At the same time, in (P1b), the energy efficiency at each transmitting worker is required to be at least e0,isubscript𝑒0𝑖e_{0,i}. Of practical importance, this constraint ensures that the total energy consumed by the wireless transmission is within a reasonable bound. Moreover, in (P1c), we guarantee that the instantaneous allocated power p​(𝐇)𝑝𝐇p({\mathbf{H}}) for every worker does not exceed an upper bound Pmaxsubscript𝑃maxP_{\mathrm{max}}.

On a side note, during a transmission round, the data rates may not remain constant, for early finishers may reduce interference in the network. Nonetheless, our solution remains feasible, as the completion of transmissions by some workers can only improve the rates of the rest and does not violate any constraints. It should be observed that optimally solving (P1) is particularly challenging. Apart from having a non-convex objective [cf. (1) and (5)] there are at least two additional sources of complexity: i) We are optimizing over the space of power allocation functions, which is inherently infinite-dimensional, and ii) We are not given a specific channel or sets of channels but rather we have to consider expected values over a whole distribution of channels. We explain how our proposed solution addresses these challenges in the next section.

IV Methods

Our method (termed primal-dual graph convolutional power network, or PDG, see Fig. 3) parameterizes the space of power allocation functions through GCNs (Section IV-B) and relies on a PD restatement of the original problem (Section IV-C). In Section IV-D, we prove that (P1) has a zero duality gap, and we show that the optimality of our solution solely depends on the expressive power of the parameterization.

IV-A The Proposed Architecture

Let us begin with a detailed explanation of Fig. 3. The PDG architecture is composed of two main components: (a) a power policy block denoted as (a) in Fig. 3 and a PD learning block (b). Notationally, d1subscript𝑑1d_{1} and dtsubscript𝑑𝑡d_{t} represent the last dimension of the trainable parameter matrices within the corresponding GCN layers. Between these layers, the elementwise activation function φtsubscript𝜑𝑡\varphi_{t} is applied, introducing non-linearities to the network’s computations.

Continuing, PDG derives three key quantities: the expected Partial Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSR) values, denoted as 𝔼​[fy]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑦\mathbb{E}[f_{y}], the conditionally expected achievable rates, denoted as 𝔼c​[fr]subscript𝔼𝑐delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑟\mathbb{E}_{c}[f_{r}], and the conditionally expected energy efficiency, denoted as 𝔼c​[fe]subscript𝔼𝑐delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑒\mathbb{E}_{c}[f_{e}]. These quantities are obtained through specific utility functions, which take as their inputs both the network topology 𝐇𝐇{\mathbf{H}} and the output 𝕡𝕡\mathbb{p} obtained at the conclusion of block (a). Importantly, these expected values correspond to the right-hand-side of the constraints outlined in equations (P2a), (P2b), and (P2c), respectively. Augmented by primal variables (𝐲𝐲{\mathbf{y}}, 𝐫𝐫{\mathbf{r}}, and 𝐞𝐞{\mathbf{e}}) and dual variables (𝝀ysubscript𝝀𝑦\bm{\lambda}_{y}, 𝝀rsubscript𝝀𝑟\bm{\lambda}_{r}, and 𝝀esubscript𝝀𝑒\bm{\lambda}_{e}), PDG formulates a parameterized Lagrangian ℒψsubscriptℒ𝜓{\mathcal{L}}_{\psi}, as expressed in (10). Additionally, this Lagrangian incorporates g​(𝐲)𝑔𝐲g({\mathbf{y}}), which represents a weighted sum of 𝐲𝐲{\mathbf{y}}, with weights determined by the predefined worker weights 𝝎𝝎\bm{\omega}.

The training process essentially completes the entire computational flow, progressing from block (a) through block (b) in a forward pass. Upon the completion of training, only the power policy is of interest for computing the allocated power vector 𝐩𝐩{\mathbf{p}}, given any unseen 𝐇𝐇{\mathbf{H}} instances.

IV-B Parameterizing Power Policies using GCNs

Using a deep graph neural architecture, we parameterize a subset of all possible power allocation policies p𝑝p. By doing so, we render the maximization in (P1) tractable by maximizing over the parameters of the neural architecture instead. To be more precise, we define

pψ​(𝐇)=Ψ​(𝐇;𝚯),subscript𝑝𝜓𝐇Ψ𝐇𝚯{\color[rgb]{0,0,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0,0,0}\pgfsys@color@gray@stroke{0}\pgfsys@color@gray@fill{0}p_{\psi}({\mathbf{H}}){\,=\,}\Psi({\mathbf{H}};\bm{\Theta}),} (8)

where ΨΨ\Psi is a T𝑇T-layer GCN with trainable parameters 𝚯𝚯\bm{\Theta}. The input to Ψ​(𝐇;𝚯)Ψ𝐇𝚯\Psi({\mathbf{H}};\bm{\Theta}) is 𝐙(0)=Pmax​𝟏superscript𝐙0subscript𝑃max1{\mathbf{Z}}^{(0)}{\,=\,}P_{\mathrm{max}}\mathbf{1} and the computation in the tthsuperscript𝑡tht^{\text{th}} layer of the GCN is given by

𝐙(t)=φt​(𝐇^​𝐙(t−1)​𝚯(t)),∀t=1,…,T,formulae-sequencesuperscript𝐙𝑡subscript𝜑𝑡^𝐇superscript𝐙𝑡1superscript𝚯𝑡for-all𝑡1…𝑇{\mathbf{Z}}^{(t)}{\,=\,}{\varphi_{t}}{\left(\hat{{\mathbf{H}}}{\mathbf{Z}}^{(t-1)}\bm{\Theta}^{(t)}\right)},\forall\,t=1,...,T, (9)

where 𝐇^=𝐃−12​𝐇𝐃−12^𝐇superscript𝐃12superscript𝐇𝐃12\hat{{\mathbf{H}}}{\,=\,}{\mathbf{D}}^{-\frac{1}{2}}{\mathbf{H}}{\mathbf{D}}^{-\frac{1}{2}} is the normalized adjacency matrix with degree matrix 𝐃=diag​(𝐇𝟏)𝐃diag𝐇𝟏{\mathbf{D}}{\,=\,}\text{diag}({\mathbf{H}}\mathbf{1}). In (9), 𝚯(t)∈ℝdt−1×dtsuperscript𝚯𝑡superscriptℝsubscript𝑑𝑡1subscript𝑑𝑡{\bm{\Theta}}^{(t)}{\,\in\,}\mathbb{R}^{d_{t-1}\times d_{t}} contains trainable parameters where dtsubscript𝑑𝑡d_{t} is the output dimension of layer t𝑡t with d0=dT= 1subscript𝑑0subscript𝑑𝑇1d_{0}{\,=\,}d_{T}{\,=\,}1, and φt​(⋅)subscript𝜑𝑡⋅\varphi_{t}(\cdot) is an elementwise activation function. In Section V, we detail the specifics of T𝑇T, dtsubscript𝑑𝑡d_{t}, φtsubscript𝜑𝑡\varphi_{t}, and other hyperparameters used in our experiments.

In principle, one may choose any architecture as the parameterization of the power policy functional space. Our particular choice of GCN in (9) not only achieves good performance in practice but is also driven by the following three appealing characteristics.

Permutation equivariance. GCNs are composed of graph filters, which are similar to convolutional filters in classical convolutional neural networks (CNNs) [44]. These graph filters learn to perform appropriate local aggregations through trainable parameters. Similar to CNNs being equivariant to translations [45], GCNs are permutation equivariant [46], meaning that the output is not affected by the ordering of nodes. Our parameterization entails a permutation equivariant power allocation policy, such that the allocated power is not affected by the indexing of workers, which is a key feature since this indexing is arbitrary.

Flexibility to varying number of workers. In FL, the possible termination of worker participation inevitably causes variations in the communication network size. Such size changes can occur within a short time, which is not enough to retrain the power allocation model. This requires the power policy to accommodate, without retraining, a number of workers L′superscript𝐿′L^{\prime} different from the L𝐿L workers with which it was trained. It thus undermines the usage of any classical deep models that require fixed input and output dimensions. It also facilitates large-network training by iteratively training on sampled subsets. Our PDG possesses this distinguishing capability by relying on GCNs [cf. (9)], a critical point to be numerically showcased in Section V.

Extensibility to heterogeneous systems. The proposed architecture exhibits easy extensibility to systems of heterogeneous devices and traffic types. For instance, by modeling the network as a multigraph, we could encode different wireless technologies or protocols as different edge types. In this case, the power policy model may be represented using relational graph convolutional networks (R-GCNs) [47] to enable effective management in multigraphs. Moreover, cases where there are different types of workers in the network can be accommodated via heterogeneous GNNs (HGNNs) [48] or graph attention networks (GATs) [49], which are particularly capable of handling different types of nodes.

IV-C Primal-Dual Augmented Constrained Learning

Having introduced the GCN parameterization of the power policy pψsubscript𝑝𝜓p_{\psi} in (8), we proceed to restate (P1) in a manner that is amenable to a PD solution

Pψ⋆superscriptsubscript𝑃𝜓⋆\displaystyle P_{\psi}^{\star} =max𝚯,𝐲,𝐫,𝐞g​(𝐲),absentsubscript𝚯𝐲𝐫𝐞𝑔𝐲\displaystyle=\max\limits_{\bm{\Theta},{\mathbf{y}},{\mathbf{r}},{\mathbf{e}}}\quad g({\mathbf{y}}), (P2)
s.t.𝐲≤𝔼​[PSR​(𝐩ψ,𝐇)],s.t.𝐲𝔼delimited-[]PSRsubscript𝐩𝜓𝐇\displaystyle\text{s.t.}\quad{\mathbf{y}}\leq{\mathbb{E}}{\left[\,\text{PSR}({\mathbf{p}}_{\psi},{\mathbf{H}})\,\right]}, (P2a)

To bring the formulation closer to a standard PD form, we introduce (P2a) with auxiliary primal variables 𝐲𝐲{\mathbf{y}}, 𝐫𝐫{\mathbf{r}}, and 𝐞𝐞{\mathbf{e}}, which will also aid in the iterative process. To treat the remaining constraints, we formulate the Lagrangian dual problem by introducing non-negative multipliers 𝝀y∈ℝ+Lsubscript𝝀𝑦superscriptsubscriptℝ𝐿\bm{\lambda}_{y}{\,\in\,}{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{L}, 𝝀r∈ℝ+Lsubscript𝝀𝑟superscriptsubscriptℝ𝐿\bm{\lambda}_{r}{\,\in\,}{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{L}, and 𝝀e∈ℝ+Lsubscript𝝀𝑒superscriptsubscriptℝ𝐿\bm{\lambda}_{e}{\,\in\,}{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{L} associated with constraints (P2a), (P2b), and (P2c), respectively. To simplify the notation, let 𝔼​[fy]𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑦{\mathbb{E}}[f_{y}] denote the expectation term and 𝔼c​[fr]subscript𝔼cdelimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑟{\mathbb{E}}_{\text{c}}[f_{r}] and 𝔼c​[fe]subscript𝔼cdelimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑒{\mathbb{E}}_{\text{c}}[f_{e}] the conditional expectation terms in constraints (P2a), (P2b), and (P2c), respectively. We enforce (P2f) simply by ensuring that the image of the last non-linearity in our GCN is contained in [0,Pmax]0subscript𝑃[0,P_{\max}]. Moreover, we denote the feasible region in (P2d) as ℛ:=[𝐫0,+∞)assignℛsubscript𝐫0{\mathcal{R}}{\,:=\,}[{\mathbf{r}}_{0},+\infty) and that in (P2e) as ℰ:=[𝐞0,+∞)assignℰsubscript𝐞0{\mathcal{E}}{\,:=\,}[{\mathbf{e}}_{0},+\infty). The Lagrangian of (P2) is then given by

ℒψ(𝚯,𝐲,𝐫,𝐞,\displaystyle{\mathcal{L}}_{\psi}(\bm{\Theta},{\mathbf{y}},{\mathbf{r}},{\mathbf{e}}, 𝝀y,𝝀r,𝝀e)=g(𝐲)+𝝀y⊤(𝔼[fy]−𝐲)\displaystyle\bm{\lambda}_{y},\bm{\lambda}_{r},\bm{\lambda}_{e})=g({\mathbf{y}})+\bm{\lambda}_{y}^{\top}({\mathbb{E}}[f_{y}]-{\mathbf{y}}) (10)
+𝝀r⊤​(𝔼c​[fr]−𝐫)+𝝀e⊤​(𝔼c​[fe]−𝐞).superscriptsubscript𝝀𝑟topsubscript𝔼cdelimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑟𝐫superscriptsubscript𝝀𝑒topsubscript𝔼cdelimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑒𝐞\displaystyle+\bm{\lambda}_{r}^{\top}({\mathbb{E}}_{\text{c}}[f_{r}]-{\mathbf{r}})+\bm{\lambda}_{e}^{\top}({\mathbb{E}}_{\text{c}}[f_{e}]-{\mathbf{e}}).

Following standard PD solutions of optimization problems [50], this Lagrangian motivates the following iterative updating approach: in the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\text{th}} iteration, the learnable parameters are updated with step size γΘ,nsubscript𝛾Θ𝑛\gamma_{\Theta,n} by

+∇Θ𝔼c[fe]𝝀e,n).\displaystyle+{\nabla_{\Theta}{\mathbb{E}}_{\text{c}}[f_{e}]\bm{\lambda}_{e,n}}). (11a)
For the primal variables, their updates follow
𝐲n+1=subscript𝐲𝑛1absent\displaystyle{\mathbf{y}}_{n+1}{\,=\,} 𝐲n+γy,n​(∇yg​(𝐲)−𝝀y,n),subscript𝐲𝑛subscript𝛾𝑦𝑛subscript∇𝑦𝑔𝐲subscript𝝀𝑦𝑛\displaystyle\,{\mathbf{y}}_{n}+\gamma_{y,n}(\nabla_{y}g({\mathbf{y}})-\bm{\lambda}_{y,n}), (11b)

where the terms γ∗,nsubscript𝛾𝑛\gamma_{*,n} represent step sizes for updating the corresponding primal variables in the current iteration. Finally, we update the dual variables
𝚲n+1=subscript𝚲𝑛1absent\displaystyle\bm{\Lambda}_{n+1}{\,=\,} [𝚲n−𝜸λ,n⊤​(𝐄−𝐗n+1)]+subscriptdelimited-[]subscript𝚲𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜸𝜆𝑛top𝐄subscript𝐗𝑛1\displaystyle\left[\bm{\Lambda}_{n}-\bm{\gamma}_{\lambda,n}^{\top}({\mathbf{E}}-{\mathbf{X}}_{n+1})\right]_{+} (11e)

𝚲n=[𝝀y,n𝝀r,n𝝀e,n],𝐄=[𝔼​[fy]𝔼c​[fr]𝔼c​[fe]],and ​𝐗n=[𝐲n𝐫n𝐞n]formulae-sequencesubscript𝚲𝑛delimited-[]matrixsubscript𝝀𝑦𝑛subscript𝝀𝑟𝑛subscript𝝀𝑒𝑛formulae-sequence𝐄delimited-[]matrix𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑦subscript𝔼cdelimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑟subscript𝔼cdelimited-[]subscript𝑓𝑒and subscript𝐗𝑛delimited-[]matrixsubscript𝐲𝑛subscript𝐫𝑛subscript𝐞𝑛\bm{\Lambda}_{n}{\,=\!}\left[\begin{matrix}\bm{\lambda}_{y,n}\\ \bm{\lambda}_{r,n}\\ \bm{\lambda}_{e,n}\end{matrix}\right],{\mathbf{E}}{\,=\!}\left[\begin{matrix}{\mathbb{E}}[f_{y}]\\ {\mathbb{E}}_{\text{c}}[f_{r}]\\ {\mathbb{E}}_{\text{c}}[f_{e}]\end{matrix}\right],\text{and }{\mathbf{X}}_{n}{\,=\!}\left[\begin{matrix}{\mathbf{y}}_{n}\\ {\mathbf{r}}_{n}\\ {\mathbf{e}}_{n}\end{matrix}\right]
denote the matrix representation of the dual, expectation, and primal variables, respectively. The standard PD solution repeats iteratively until convergence.

In our implementation, we approximate the expected values in (11a) and (11e) through their empirical counterparts by drawing batches of CSI instances from ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}}. This above process can be implemented to learn the parameters 𝚯𝚯\bm{\Theta} that maximize the objective in (P2).

IV-D Optimality Analysis

In this section, we first show that (P1) has a zero duality gap, thus theoretically motivating the use of a PD approach as described in Section IV-C. Then, we show that the optimality gap in (P2) depends linearly on the approximation capability of the parameterization of the policy function.

We show the first result on a generalized version of (P1), stated as follows

P⋆=maxp⁡v​(p),s.t.superscript𝑃⋆subscript𝑝𝑣𝑝s.t.\displaystyle\mathit{P}^{\star}=\max\limits_{p}\,\,v(p),\quad\text{s.t.}\,\, ui​(p)≥ci,∀i,subscript𝑢𝑖𝑝subscript𝑐𝑖for-all𝑖\displaystyle u_{i}(p)\geq c_{i},\forall\,i,\quad p∈𝒫,𝑝𝒫\displaystyle p\in{\mathcal{P}}, (P1′)

with v​(p)=g​(𝔼​[f0​(𝐩,𝐇)])𝑣𝑝𝑔𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑓0𝐩𝐇v(p){\,=\,}g({\mathbb{E}}[f_{0}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}})]) for some objective function f0:ℝL×ℝL×L→ℝL:subscript𝑓0→superscriptℝ𝐿superscriptℝ𝐿𝐿superscriptℝ𝐿f_{0}{\,:\,}{\mathbb{R}}^{L}{\times}{\mathbb{R}}^{L{\times}L}{\,\rightarrow\,}{\mathbb{R}}^{L} (e.g., PSR) and a utility function g:ℝL→ℝ:𝑔→superscriptℝ𝐿ℝg{\,:\,}{\mathbb{R}}^{L}{\,\rightarrow\,}{\mathbb{R}} (e.g., the weighted sum). The constraints are described by ui​(p)=𝔼​[fci​(𝐩,𝐇)​|pi>​ 0]subscript𝑢𝑖𝑝𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsubscript𝑓c𝑖𝐩𝐇ketsubscript𝑝𝑖 0u_{i}(p){\,=\,}{\mathbb{E}}[{f_{\text{c}}}_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}})\,|\,p_{i}{\,>\,}0] as the expectation of constraint function(s) fci:ℝL×ℝL×L→ℝ:subscriptsubscript𝑓c𝑖→superscriptℝ𝐿superscriptℝ𝐿𝐿ℝ{f_{\text{c}}}_{i}{\,:\,}{\mathbb{R}}^{L}{\times}{\mathbb{R}}^{L{\times}L}{\,\rightarrow\,}{\mathbb{R}} (e.g., data rate or energy efficiency) conditioned on transmitting workers and ci≥ 0subscript𝑐𝑖 0c_{i}{\,\geq\,}0 as the constraint value for worker i𝑖i. For simplicity, we will show our result for the case of a single constraint function fcisubscriptsubscript𝑓c𝑖{f_{\text{c}}}_{i} for each worker, but the same result holds for any finite number of constraint functions (e.g., two in the case of (P1)). The set 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}} describes a feasible policy function space as, e.g., the one stated in (P1c). Notice that (P1′) is a more general formulation than our problem of interest (P1).

To establish our results, we rely on several assumptions that are common in literature on similar topics [40]:

(AS1) The probability distribution ℋℋ{\mathcal{H}} is non-atomic.

(AS2) The utility function g​(⋅)𝑔⋅g(\cdot) is concave and non-decreasing.

(AS3) Denoting by p⋆superscript𝑝⋆p^{\star} an optimal solution to (P1′), the set 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}} is given by

𝒫={p|\displaystyle{\mathcal{P}}=\{p\,| p​(𝐇)∈[0,Pmax],𝑝𝐇0subscript𝑃\displaystyle\,p({\mathbf{H}}){\,\in\,}[0,P_{\max}], (12)
𝟙(pi(𝐇)=0)=𝟙(pi⋆(𝐇)=0)∀i,𝐇}.\displaystyle\mathds{1}(p_{i}({\mathbf{H}})=0)=\mathds{1}(p^{\star}_{i}({\mathbf{H}})=0)\,\,\,\forall i,{\mathbf{H}}\}.

Most of these assumptions are naturally satisfied by our problem at hand. In particular, (AS1) is satisfied for channel models that depend on continuous probability distributions (e.g., the Rayleigh fading channels) from which we then compute the CSI matrix via (2). Regarding (AS2), our weighted sum utility function on PSR values in (6) evidently satisfies this assumption. In terms of (AS3), the maximum power constraint Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} on all feasible policies is also a natural requirement. In the second part of (12), we require knowledge of the optimal worker selection 𝟙​(pi⋆​(𝐇)=0)1subscriptsuperscript𝑝⋆𝑖𝐇0\mathds{1}(p^{\star}_{i}({\mathbf{H}})=0). In other words, we do not know the optimal power allocation (since that is what we are optimizing for), but we assume knowledge of whether this optimal power is either zero or non-zero for every worker i𝑖i and channel 𝐇𝐇{\mathbf{H}}. Admittedly, this is a stringent assumption that will be leveraged in showing our theoretical results. Nevertheless, notice that in our experiments (Section V), we do not assume access to this knowledge and the proposed method still performs satisfactorily in practice.

Under the introduced assumptions, the following result holds.

Theorem 1.

If problem (P1′) is feasible, then, under assumptions (AS1)-(AS3), it has a zero duality gap.

Proof.

Let us define the following set

𝒞={𝝃∈ℝL+1|∃p∈𝒫,v​(p)≥ξ0,ui​(p)≥ξi+ci,∀i}.𝒞conditional-set𝝃superscriptℝ𝐿1formulae-sequence𝑝𝒫formulae-sequence𝑣𝑝subscript𝜉0subscript𝑢𝑖𝑝subscript𝜉𝑖subscript𝑐𝑖for-all𝑖{\mathcal{C}}=\{\bm{\xi}\in{\mathbb{R}}^{L+1}\,|\,\exists\,p\in{\mathcal{P}},v(p)\geq\xi_{0},u_{i}(p)\geq\xi_{i}+c_{i},\forall\,i\}.

The feasibility of (P1′) guarantees that 𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} is not empty since (P⋆,0,…,0)∈𝒞superscript𝑃⋆0…0𝒞(\mathit{P}^{\star},0,...,0){\,\in\,}{\mathcal{C}}, where P⋆superscript𝑃⋆\mathit{P}^{\star} is the maximum objective achievable by that problem.

Lemma 1.

𝒞𝒞{\mathcal{C}} is a convex set. (See proof in Appendix B.)

Let us define the Lagrangian of (P1′) as

ℒ​(p,𝝀)=v​(p)+∑i=1Lλi​(ui​(p)−ci),for ​λi∈ℝ+,formulae-sequenceℒ𝑝𝝀𝑣𝑝subscriptsuperscript𝐿𝑖1subscript𝜆𝑖subscript𝑢𝑖𝑝subscript𝑐𝑖for subscript𝜆𝑖subscriptℝ{\mathcal{L}}(p,\bm{\lambda})=v(p)+\sum\limits^{L}_{i=1}\lambda_{i}(u_{i}(p)-c_{i}),\text{for }\lambda_{i}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+},

and hence the dual value is given by

D⋆=min𝝀∈ℝ+L⁡maxp∈𝒫⁡ℒ​(p,𝝀).superscript𝐷⋆subscript𝝀superscriptsubscriptℝ𝐿subscript𝑝𝒫ℒ𝑝𝝀D^{\star}=\min\limits_{\bm{\lambda}\in{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{L}}\,\max\limits_{p\in{\mathcal{P}}}\,{\mathcal{L}}(p,\bm{\lambda}).

In showing that D⋆=P⋆superscript𝐷⋆superscript𝑃⋆D^{\star}{\,=\,}\mathit{P}^{\star}, we already have D⋆≥P⋆superscript𝐷⋆superscript𝑃⋆D^{\star}{\,\geq\,}\mathit{P}^{\star} due to weak duality. What is left here is to show that D⋆≤P⋆superscript𝐷⋆superscript𝑃⋆D^{\star}{\,\leq\,}\mathit{P}^{\star}, which can be achieved by finding some 𝝀~∈ℝ+L~𝝀superscriptsubscriptℝ𝐿\tilde{\bm{\lambda}}{\,\in\,}{\mathbb{R}}_{+}^{L} such that

∎

Inspired by [40, Theorem 1], one can further show that the optimality gap of the parameterized (P2) depends linearly on the approximation capabilities of the parameterization of the policy function. This suggests that if our proposed pψsubscript𝑝𝜓p_{\psi} is a good parameterization of the power policy space, then the solution given by the PD learning iterations in (11a)-(11e) will be close to the optimal solution of our original problem (P1). Let us elaborate on this point by deriving the bounds of the parameterized dual value, starting with generalizing (P2) as follows

We require two additional assumptions to bound the error introduced by the parameterization.

(AS4) The constraint functions fci​(𝐩,𝐇)subscriptsubscript𝑓c𝑖𝐩𝐇{f_{\text{c}}}_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}}) are expectation-wise Lipschitz on 𝐩𝐩{\mathbf{p}} for all 𝐇𝐇{\mathbf{H}}. More precisely, for any pair of power allocations 𝐩1=p1​(𝐇)superscript𝐩1superscript𝑝1𝐇{\mathbf{p}}^{1}=p^{1}({\mathbf{H}}) and 𝐩2=p2​(𝐇)superscript𝐩2superscript𝑝2𝐇{\mathbf{p}}^{2}=p^{2}({\mathbf{H}}) for p1,p2∈𝒫superscript𝑝1superscript𝑝2𝒫p^{1},p^{2}\in{\mathcal{P}}, there exists a constant L𝐿L such that

𝔼[|fci(𝐩1,𝐇)\displaystyle{\mathbb{E}}[|{f_{\text{c}}}_{i}({\mathbf{p}}^{1},{\mathbf{H}}) −fci(𝐩2,𝐇)||[𝐩1]i> 0 and [𝐩2]i> 0]\displaystyle-{f_{\text{c}}}_{i}({\mathbf{p}}^{2},{\mathbf{H}})|\,\,\big{|}\,\,[{\mathbf{p}}^{1}]_{i}{\,>\,}0\text{ and }[{\mathbf{p}}^{2}]_{i}{\,>\,}0]

(AS5) The parameterization pψ​(⋅;𝚯)subscript𝑝𝜓⋅𝚯p_{\psi}(\cdot;\bm{\Theta}) is ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon-universal in 𝒫𝒫{\mathcal{P}}. More precisely, for any p∈𝒫𝑝𝒫p\in{\mathcal{P}} there exist parameters 𝚯𝚯\bm{\Theta} such that

𝔼​[‖p​(𝐇)−pψ​(⋅;𝚯)‖]≤ϵ.𝔼delimited-[]norm𝑝𝐇subscript𝑝𝜓⋅𝚯italic-ϵ{\mathbb{E}}[\|p({\mathbf{H}})-p_{\psi}(\cdot;\bm{\Theta})\|]\leq\epsilon.

Notice that (AS4) is immediately satisfied by constraint functions fci​(𝐩,𝐇)subscriptsubscript𝑓c𝑖𝐩𝐇{f_{\text{c}}}_{i}({\mathbf{p}},{\mathbf{H}}) that are Lipschitz continuous on 𝐩∈(0,Pmax]𝐩0subscript𝑃{\mathbf{p}}{\,\in\,}(0,P_{\max}], such as those considered in our problem of interest. Furthermore, (AS5) is not as much an assumption of our problem but rather a statement about the quality of the parameterization adopted. With this notation in place, the following result holds.

Theorem 2.

If problem (P2′) is feasible then, under assumptions (AS1)-(AS5), its dual value Dψ⋆superscriptsubscript𝐷𝜓⋆D_{\psi}^{\star} in (15) is bounded by

P⋆−L​ϵ​(‖𝝀y⋆‖1+‖𝝀c⋆‖1)≤Dψ⋆≤P⋆+L​ϵ​‖𝝀c⋆‖1,superscript𝑃⋆𝐿italic-ϵsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝝀𝑦⋆1subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝝀𝑐⋆1superscriptsubscript𝐷𝜓⋆superscript𝑃⋆𝐿italic-ϵsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝝀𝑐⋆1P^{\star}{\,-\,}\!L\epsilon\left(\|\bm{\lambda}_{y}^{\star}\|_{1}+\|\bm{\lambda}_{c}^{\star}\|_{1}\right)\leq D_{\psi}^{\star}\leq P^{\star}+\,L\epsilon\|\bm{\lambda}_{c}^{\star}\|_{1}, (17)

where L𝐿L and ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon are the constants in (AS4) and (AS5), respectively.

Proof.

See Appendix C. ∎

As revealed by Theorem 2, the dual value of the parameterized problem (P2′) becomes closer to the primal value of the non-parameterized counterpart (P1′) as ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon decreases. Indeed, a smaller ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon entails a richer parametric family of policies pΨsubscript𝑝Ψp_{\Psi}, reducing the difference between the parameterized and non-parameterized versions of the problem. In the limit, when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon approaches zero, we recover the null duality gap result in Theorem 1. It is worth noting that small values of L𝐿L can also lead to smaller gaps since smaller L𝐿L typically corresponds to better-behaved constraints [cf. (16)]. In practice, we nevertheless make a choice of parameterization that leads to not only a small duality gap but also a good trade-off between expressiveness and tractability. A neural network with deep and specialized architecture can achieve both an accurate approximation of the original problem and efficient optimization of the parameterized problem. For instance, our proposed PDG (Fig. 3) can result in good empirical performance, as we demonstrate in the next section. We also compare PDG to a PD solution based on multi-layer perceptrons (MLP) – whose universal approximation capabilities are well established [51] – and empirically show that the specialized architecture of PDG helps us outperform the graph-agnostic learning method.

V Numerical experiments

We evaluate the proposed power allocation method PDG111Code to implement the proposed method is available at https://github.com/bl166/WirelessFL-PDG. within the standard FL pipeline (Fig. 4) based on either of the two following assumptions – i.i.d. and non-i.i.d. local data distribution. The performance of the power allocation methods is assessed using two metrics, namely the wireless transmission performance and the prediction performance of the FL global model. Before delving into results and insights, let us first introduce the data preparation, experiment setups, and candidate power policies.

For wireless channels, we employ the same data generator as in [15] to simulate wideband spatial (WBS) interference networks with Rayleigh fading effects222https://github.com/bmatthiesen/deep-EE-opt. served by one BS with nR= 10subscript𝑛𝑅10n_{R}{\,=\,}10 antennas. The downlink communication cost is considered negligible while we focus on the uplink transmission from workers to servers. A number of 3000 channel realizations are generated and equally split into training (to update model parameters), validation (to select the best-performing epoch for test), and testing (to report the performance) sets. Training is consistently conducted with 8-worker networks, and the default configuration for testing is also using 8-worker networks. For the remaining system configuration, Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} is default at −20​dBW20dBW-20\,\text{dBW} in all experiments except for the one that specifically targets at different Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} values. Following every intermediate layer t= 1,⋯,T−1𝑡1⋯𝑇1t{\,=\,}1,\cdots,T{-}1, Exponential Linear Unit (ELU) is used as the non-linear activation function φtsubscript𝜑𝑡\varphi_{t}; following the last layer t=T𝑡𝑇t{\,=\,}T, we apply a scaled sigmoid to guarantee that the output power is contained in [0,Pmax]0subscript𝑃[0,P_{\max}]. Learning rates γΘ= 10−3subscript𝛾Θsuperscript103\gamma_{\Theta}{\,=\,}10^{-3} and γ{y,r,e,λy,λr,λe}= 10−4subscript𝛾𝑦𝑟𝑒subscript𝜆𝑦subscript𝜆𝑟subscript𝜆𝑒superscript104\gamma_{\{y,r,e,\lambda_{y},\lambda_{r},\lambda_{e}\}}{\,=\,}10^{-4} are fixed for all iterations. A very small clamping value of 10−20superscript102010^{-20} is set to stabilize the training process; if the predicted power is smaller than this value, it will be considered practically zero. A total of 1000 PD learning epochs are performed in an unsupervised manner with early termination given unimproved performance in 100 consecutive epochs.

The plots presented in Fig. 5 illustrate the convergence of the PDG method on the validation channels. Fig. 5(a) and 5(b) display the worker-wise values pertaining to the right-hand-side of inequalities (P2b) and (P2c), which represent delay and energy constraints, respectively. To provide context, horizontal dashed lines denote the empirically selected constraint constants, which remain uniform across all workers. Successful instances where all workers satisfy both constraints are marked with blue dots on the objective curve in Fig. 5(c). This plot also demonstrates the growth of the objective value in (P2) as the learning progresses. From these convergence plots, it becomes evident that PDG excels in learning to maximize the objective while upholding both constraints simultaneously. Subsequently, we compare PDG to one learning-based and two model-based baselines:

  • 1)

    Rand is a random power policy that independently samples individual workers’ transmit power from a uniform distribution ∼𝒰​(0,Pmax)similar-toabsent𝒰0subscript𝑃\sim{\mathcal{U}}(0,P_{\max}). Occasionally, the randomly chosen power for worker i𝑖i violates the energy constraint. In these cases, worker i𝑖i is reassigned pi= 0subscript𝑝𝑖 0p_{i}{\,=\,}0.

  • 2)

    Orth is the optimal power policy for orthogonal channels originally proposed in [16]. It results in the participating worker i𝑖i transmitting at pi=min⁡{Pmax,PE,i}subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑃subscript𝑃E𝑖p_{i}{\,=\,}\min\{P_{\max},P_{\text{E},i}\}, where PE,isubscript𝑃E𝑖P_{\text{E},i} is the maximum power for worker i𝑖i that satisfies the energy constraint.

  • 3)

    PDM is a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) power policy model trained following the same PD algorithm as PDG. Its input consists of the concatenation of the flattened 𝐇𝐇{\mathbf{H}} and Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max}. It is propagated through 5 hidden layers of {128,256,64,16,8}12825664168\{128,256,64,16,8\} neurons and the Leaky ReLU non-linearity in between. The final activation function is identical to that of the proposed architecture.

In order to guarantee that all constraints in (P1) are met, the Rand and Orth allocation methods require explicit worker selection after the power is determined for all candidate workers. A subset of workers satisfying the constraints will participate in the current FL iteration. In the learning-based methods PDM and PDG, however, post-allocation worker selection is not necessary. Instead, the models learn from data to automatically meet the constraints even for unseen instances. To be precise, some workers may be assigned zero transmit power and thus excluded from participating. In this way, our experiments confirm that the constraints are satisfied on unseen channels through appropriate training.

V-A Communication Proxy Evaluation

Transmission over different interference intensities. In this experiment, we study the impact of the strength of wireless multiuser interference. To this end, we scale the interference coefficients (βi​jsubscript𝛽𝑖𝑗\beta_{ij}) in the CSI matrices by {1,2,4,8} and compare the transmission performance of candidate methods in those modified networks. Training and the subsequent testing are conducted at each scaling factor. Fig. 6(a) shows a communication proxy to the final FL errors, namely the weighted sum PER of all the workers that transmit. Although for orthogonal channels, Orth is the optimal power policy, its performance within non-orthogonal channels is only comparable with that of Rand. In contrast, the two PD learning methods achieve smaller PER via learning from sufficient channel samples. Furthermore, the graph-based PDG can transmit with even fewer errors than the topology-agnostic PDM in all tested interference intensities.

Transmission performance versus maximum power capability. In Fig. 6(b), we compare the transmission performance of candidate power allocation methods against different upper bounds of transmit power in {−40,−30,−20,−10,0}​dBW403020100dBW\{-40,-30,-20,-10,0\}\,\text{dBW}. Training and the subsequent testing are conducted at each Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} level. Intuitively, the choice of Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} may reflect in fundamentally different bottlenecks in power allocation. When Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} is small enough, we are essentially looking at a trivial case where the multiuser interference is small and the bottleneck is the power magnitude itself. Consequently, it can be optimized by simply transmitting at the maximum power whenever possible. All power policies that can either naturally follow (e.g., Orth) or pick up (e.g., PDM and PDG) this strategy have the gap between their performance closed. On the contrary, Rand fails because it cannot enforce the maximum power strategy. As Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} grows, however, interference gradually becomes the major limitation. Thus, we observe that the advantage of PDG’s policy is more conspicuous for larger Pmaxsubscript𝑃P_{\max} (high interference) settings.

Transmission for different number of workers. It is important in practice that a power policy generalizes well across different network sizes, so that one can apply a pretrained model in other wireless networks. In this sense, PDG is preferred over PDM, for its GCN-based power policy is versatile whereas the MLP-based power policy of the latter can only take fixed input and output dimensions. Also, the permutation equivariance of GCN suggests that PDG is not only applicable but also robust to changes in network size. To show this, we investigate the transmission performance of the candidate models in different-sized FL systems and show the comparison in Fig. 6(c). Despite training only using an 8-worker system, PDG consistently demonstrates better wireless uplink transmission than the other two baselines in {6,8,16,24,32}68162432\{6,8,16,24,32\}-worker systems. Moreover, the performance degradation of PDG due to increased multiuser interference is not as bad as that of Orth and Rand, which further underscores its generalizability.

Transmission based on noisy channel information. Channel estimation has been a subject of extensive research, leading to a variety of approaches designed to estimate wireless scenarios with differing complexities and accuracy levels [52, 53]. However, it is crucial to recognize that in real-world scenarios, our assumption of perfect channel knowledge may not hold true. Therefore, we conduct an experiment where noisy channel estimates are taken as input to the power allocation methods. After getting the allocations, we evaluate them using the actual channels to check their PER performance. Noisy channel estimates are simulated using additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) of appropriate variances. As shown on the x-axis of Fig. 6(d), different levels of variances are used to sample AWGN, which is then added to the input 𝐇𝐇{\mathbf{H}} [cf. (2)] to the allocation methods. This is done to mimic the practically inevitable imperfection in channel knowledge. This plot gives an idea of how the PER of the PD learning methods increases as a result of the deteriorating quality of channel estimation. Both bear witness to a similar performance degradation, yet PDG consistently performs better than PDM. Note that it is reasonable that Rand and Orth are insensitive to noise because their proposed power schemes do not depend on specific channel realizations.

V-B Analysis of Allocated Power and Simulated Transmissions

To reveal the source of performance gains that the proposed method provides, we show the histograms of allocated power of the test channel set given by PDG and PDM in Fig. 7. These 8-worker channel samples are all subject to a maximum transmit power of −20​dBW20dBW{-}20\,\text{dBW} (i.e., 0≤p≤ 0.01​W0𝑝0.01W0{\,\leq\,}p{\,\leq\,}0.01\,\text{W}, as shown on the horizontal axis). It is clear how different the two power distributions are, in the sense that the PDM allocation tends to set maximum power allocation in a large number of cases (the tallest bar rightmost at 0.01​W0.01W0.01\,\text{W}) while suppressing transmissions for most of the others. In contrast, PDG can make finer and fairer allocations, from which one can easily observe that most of the allocated power values are smoothly distributed around 5​mW5mW5\,\text{mW}.

Next, we proceed to perform the FL training process using real-world datasets. At the beginning of each FL global iteration, a channel instance is independently sampled from a WBS channel distribution. With this dynamic setting of the wireless environment, the FL process is simulated on a (by default) 8-worker system for 50 global iterations. The uplink transmissions at each iteration are simulated based on the computed PER values (which are used as probabilities with which transmission may fail) of individual workers. We display a box plot of the average number of successful transmissions made on one attempt (Fig. 8). Since the system has 8 workers, this number will be 8 in the ideal case (marked as ‘Ideal FL’ in the figure) where everyone gets to transmit with no loss, as shown in the figure. We plot the boxes for each candidate allocation method, and PDG performance is observed to have not only the largest average but also the smallest variance. The methods of PDM, Orth, and Rand have worse performance. Thus, it is reasonable to expect that the PDG will result in the best FL performance (in the i.i.d. data case, at least), which we verify in the next section.

V-C Learning Performance of i.i.d. Federated Tasks

The power allocation methods in this paper serve the ultimate goal of promoting the convergence speed and learning accuracy of FL tasks. In this regard, we test their performance on three FL tasks of different types: regression, binary text classification, and multi-class image classification.

Air quality regression. We consider air quality prediction using the UCI Air Quality dataset [54], which includes 8-dimensional hourly sensor features and hourly averaged O3subscriptO3\text{O}_{3} levels as ground truth. The number of data samples at each worker is drawn from a uniform distribution 𝒰​(20,200)𝒰20200{\mathcal{U}}(20,200). This models the particularly challenging scenario where local workers only have access to a limited amount of data.

The regression learning model is a single-layer (50 hidden nodes) feedforward neural network with hyperbolic tangent non-linearity and mean-square error loss. Recalling the definition of the objective g𝑔g in (6), we determine the worker-specific weights 𝐰𝐰{\mathbf{w}} in g𝑔g based on the size of each worker’s local dataset resulting from the uniform sampling process just introduced. During local training, we use a batch size of 8 and the Adam optimizer with an empirical learning rate of 8×10−48superscript1048{\times}10^{-4} for 50 FL iterations.

A dynamic wireless environment is simulated by generating a new channel realization from the same WBS distribution at the beginning of every FL iteration. Then, pretrained (or preset) power allocation methods are applied to determine the transmit power at each worker for uploading their local models to the server in the current FL iteration. Also based on the real-time channels, the PER of each transmission is computed, which provides the probabilities from which we draw the transmission outcomes (successful or not). Should a transmission be deemed successful, the corresponding local model will be integrated into the global [cf. (7)] in the current FL iteration.

In terms of the local training, owing to the limited number of local samples, participating workers perform a full epoch with their own on-device data during each FL iteration. To provide an empirical upper bound of FL performance, we consider the ideal FL scenario where transmission is lossless (i.e., all workers transmit with 100%percent100100\% success rate in all iterations). We report the average performance of the scaled root-mean-square errors (RMSE) against the number of FL iterations on a 100-sample test set over 10 random runs, as shown in Fig. 9.

Text sentiment classification. We leverage the Internet Movie Database (IMDb) reviews dataset [55] for binary sentiment classification. This task serves as a benchmark for understanding sentiment in text data. The IMDb dataset contains 50K data samples of balanced positive and negative sentiment labels. We reserve a subset of 7500 samples for test and randomly distribute another subset of 17.5K samples among 8 workers, ensuring that the ratio ki/Ksubscript𝑘𝑖𝐾k_{i}{/}K is identical to that of the previous task for all i𝑖i.

We employ 50-dimensional pre-trained word embeddings [56] in conjunction with a bidirectional long short-term memory network (BiLSTM) [57], comprising 2 layers, each with 128 hidden nodes. Due to the increased dataset size, we increase the batch size to 100 for the sake of efficiency. Binary cross-entropy loss and the Adam optimizer with an empirical learning rate of 0.0020.0020.002 are utilized.

The wireless setups are similar to the regression case, including the transmission-loss-free reference of ideal FL. Each time global aggregation occurs, we assess the performance of the global model by computing its classification error rate on the test set. Based on various power allocation methods, the results are shown in Fig. 10. Similar to the first case, we report their average performance over 10 random realizations.

Image classification. We use the MNIST dataset [55] for multiclass classification, which consists of 28×28282828{\times}28 binary images (later flattened as 784784784-element vectors) representing handwritten digits from 0 through 9. This task follows the same essential setups as the regression case, also including the number of hidden nodes and non-linearity in the FL model. In the meantime, we make some modifications to better suit the multi-class classification task. The input dimension is increased to 784, and the output dimension is set to 10 to accommodate the classification of 10 classes. Additionally, we use the cross-entropy loss, a learning rate of 0.0010.0010.001, and 16 samples per mini-batch for local model training based on experimentation.

More notably, having a large number of MNIST samples available, we are able to increase the size of local datasets by 25×25{\times}. It therefore enables each worker to hold between 500 to 5000 data samples. Subsequently, instead of performing a full local epoch at each FL iteration, we utilize a fixed number of 5 local iterations that may not necessarily transverse all local samples. A total of 100 FL iterations are performed. This strategy facilitates synchronization and improves efficiency by minimizing wait time for workers with a large number of samples to complete training. These modifications are necessary to ensure that the FL model can adequately handle the classification task and produce reliable results.

Similar to the regression case, we report the average performance in Fig. 11, measured by the prediction error rate, on a left-out test set of 1000 samples over 10 random realizations.

The key takeaways are consistent across Figs. 9, 10, and 11. Tested with various data and learning models, FL with PDG consistently outperforms all other competitors. It is showcased that PDG accelerates the convergence speed of wireless FL, stabilizes the learning processes, and narrows the performance gap toward the ideal FL scenario. In particular, Fig. 10 provides clear examples of federated convergence failure when the transmit power is allocated using naive policies, namely Rand and Orth. This can be attributed to the large size of LSTM parameters and the complexity of the text task, underlining once again the significance of selecting an appropriate power allocation method for challenging FL tasks.

V-D Non-i.i.d. Data Distribution

Non-i.i.d. assumptions are reasonable in cases where the FL workers have access to different classes of labels and quality of data. In this section, we employ the MNIST dataset once again to show two typical non-i.i.d. cases where i) Local datasets contain additive white Gaussian noise of different levels (Fig. 12(a)), and ii) The label distribution in each worker is skewed (Fig. 12(b)).

In the first non-i.i.d. scenario, local feature distributions are skewed, i.e., 𝐧i∼𝒩ki×w×h​(0,ηi2)similar-tosubscript𝐧𝑖subscript𝒩subscript𝑘𝑖𝑤ℎ0superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖2{\mathbf{n}}_{i}{\,\sim\,}{\mathcal{N}}_{k_{i}\times w\times h}(0,\eta_{i}^{2}), where 𝐧isubscript𝐧𝑖{\mathbf{n}}_{i} is the noise added to the kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} images of size w×h𝑤ℎw{\,\times\,}h at worker i𝑖i, and ηi2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑖2\eta_{i}^{2} is the worker-specific noise variance. Intuitively, the less noisy the data of a worker, the more important it should be. Hence, we define an empirical mapping from noise levels to importance scores as ωi=exp⁡[2−ηi−min⁡(𝜼)30],∀isubscript𝜔𝑖2subscript𝜂𝑖𝜼30for-all𝑖\omega_{i}{\,=\,}\exp[2-\frac{\eta_{i}-\min(\bm{\eta})}{30}],\forall i. Fig. 12(a) displays the worker importance scores 𝝎𝝎\bm{\omega} as will appear in (6) and the corresponding noisy versions of a digit. This is for illustrative purposes only, since the actual dataset contains different images for each worker, and therefore they would not have different noisy versions of the same digit.

In the second non-i.i.d. scenario, local label distributions are skewed. In other words, FL workers are prone to imbalanced data labels on top of uneven local data quantities. We simulate this imbalance using a Dirichlet distribution, which is a common approach to create a controllable level of label skewness by partitioning a balanced dataset into subsets containing imbalanced labels [58, 59]. More precisely, we sample 𝜽d∼DirL​(κ)similar-tosubscript𝜽𝑑subscriptDir𝐿𝜅\bm{\theta}_{d}{\,\sim\,}\text{Dir}_{L}(\kappa), with κ𝜅\kappa being a concentration parameter, and assign a θd,isubscript𝜃𝑑𝑖\theta_{d,i} proportion of class-d𝑑d data to worker i𝑖i. Tuning κ𝜅\kappa smaller results in more imbalanced distributions. We tested several choices of κ𝜅\kappa and empirically fix on κ= 1𝜅1\kappa{\,=\,}1. Having partitioned the entire dataset, we randomly sample a desired number kisubscript𝑘𝑖k_{i} of data instances as the local dataset for each worker i𝑖i. The consequent local label histograms can be found in Fig. 12(b).

Fig. 13 summarizes the results of non-i.i.d. wireless FL experiments in which the power schemes are determined by the candidate and proposed allocation approaches. It can be observed that the FL models resulting from PDG always produce more stable and accurate performance than competitors in learning to classify handwritten digits. These results suggest that PDG can serve as a promising power solution for enabling efficient and reliable wireless FL in real-world scenarios.

VI Conclusion

We developed a data-driven approach that can efficiently allocate transmit power for FL workers given channel instances and limited local information. The allocation is based on GCNs whose parameters are optimized through a primal-dual learning algorithm. Formal statements regarding the optimality of the proposed method were presented. From a practical viewpoint, we successfully demonstrated the efficacy of the proposed method in (approximately) solving the associated non-convex constrained optimization problem. Through extensive analyses and experiments, we have also highlighted additional appealing characteristics of the proposed approach such as robustness to the number of workers. In addition, we have verified the proposed method in various challenging wireless and FL scenarios such as imperfect channel information and non-i.i.d. data at local workers.

In the future, there lies an intriguing avenue for modeling more variables, such as channel coherence time, worker mobility or velocity, and time-varying constraint bounds, which are often encountered in real-world scenarios. We are also interested in enhancing PD learning with adaptive step size when updating the variables and advanced graph network architectures. Incorporating these additional dimensions would enrich our resource management capabilities for wireless FL systems and applications.
